question: So what's in store for us in tomorrow's column?
answer: I don't know yet. I'm kind of a last- minute man. Ideas don't flow until an hour or two before deadline.

question: This is very interesting. You get your ideas for your column from life. You start up a conversation with a woman in a bar, attack her choice of reading material, try and get a rise out of her while you contemplate whether or not she's worth hitting on.
answer: No, I can't hit on you until I get an idea.

question: That's flattering.
answer: No, you don't understand.

question: I think I do understand. So my not responding to your baiting me will inspire one of those potential bitter diatribes you love to write about women and all the things we do to drive men crazy?
answer: I don't write bitter diatribes about women... very often.

question: Only when the ideas aren't flowing, huh? Well, it was very nice to meet you, one-minute man.
answer: That's last minute man. And it's the quality that counts.

question: Holy moly.
answer: "What is unusual about Miss Carpenter is that she likes to dress her men up as grooms before she devours them. She has already disemboweled six in a row by leaving them at the altar."... I can't ready anymore.

question: "And her ritual feast continues as she prepares to make a sacrifice out of the seventh fiance. So all bets are on and we hope that this boomerang bride isn't honeymooning with Las Vegas odds makers because many predict that this girl is out of there before the race... before the rice hits the ground" Holy moly. You tell Maggie.
answer: No, you tell her.

question: No, no. You're her best friend.
answer: No.

question: You know, it's just possible that she hasn't read this yet.
answer: Yeah.

question: Since when does Ellie need moral supp--
answer: -- It's for you, Ike.

question: What?
answer: Journalism lesson number one. If you fabricate your facts, you get fired.

question: Lesson number two. Never work for your former spouse.
answer: That's not nothing to do with it. You cooked this story up and you know it.

question: I didn't cook up a story. I had a source.
answer: Someone reliable, I'm sure. A booze- hound in a bar?

question: Don't knock drunk guys in bars. Drunk guys in bars are good. It means they're not driving.
answer: No, that's what makes you unemployed.

question: I merely write the stuff. You're the one that serves it up.
answer: Not anymore. I have to draw the line. She sent us this list. Our lawyers say it's actionable.

question: Lawyers. I don't know, Ellie -- Firing me is going to be very tough on you. It's going to be hard to get over. There will be therapy bills for you.
answer: I already made an appointment for later today.

question: See? You want custody of my job? ... Why not just consider my wrist slapped and call me when you feel I've served my time?
answer: I'm sorry, Ike. This is permanent.

question: Ike, I really liked the Runaway Bride piece, and since I do freelance stuff for G.Q., I'm in a different position now...
answer: What are you trying to say to me, Fish?

question: Vindication. How would you like to get some? A chance to prove that, though your facts weren't entirely straight, your theory was correct.
answer: The real story on Miss Carpenter.

question: All the gory details.
answer: The anatomy of the black widow spider of Maryland.

question: It wouldn't be a bad way to get you back into writing feature pieces again.
answer: This is good. It is a good story, Fish.

question: If she runs, then it's a cover story. All true. All accurate.
answer: Okay, you were right. I hated my column, but I can do this assignment.

question: Then you've got it. If you leave tomorrow for the hinterlands, you'll have plenty of time before her next wedding trot.
answer: "Paid vindication" That's what I call justice.

question: Justice, yes. Paid, I don't know. They like the idea, but my hands are tied with budget restraints.
answer: But I'll get my normal fee, right? You want me to do it on spec?!

question: Don't say "spec" like it's a dirty word. Nobody ever paid Shakespeare to write a play! Plato never got a book advance...
answer: Oh yeah! I happen to know from reliable sources that Nietzche got expenses and a rental car. I think I'm in Maryberry.

question: Stop it. When you talk like that, I get turned on and it frightens me.
answer: Hello. I'm looking for Maggie Carpenter. There was a sign at the hardware store across the street...

question: Are you a reporter?
answer: What?

question: It's been our experience that anyone with some sort of gewgaw on his loafers ends up being another big city reporter wanting to interview Maggie.
answer: About her upcoming wedding and all.

question: No, about her getting that asshole from New York fired.
answer: I am just such a reporter. And you are?

question: Peggy Phleming. Not the ice skater.
answer: And who are these lovely ladies?

question: Sorry, no. I just got one.
answer: Excuse me, sir. I have an actual fact for you.

question: Yes, Mrs. Pressman.
answer: It's her fourth time to the altar, you know. Not seven like they said.

question: Have a seat. Peggy, why don't you give him the special treatment that strengthens the follicles.
answer: Getting nervous?

question: Nervous? Not at all! No. I've never been more certain in my life. Except -- I am having all kinds of weird dreams.
answer: Weird dreams? You're going to tell me about them?

question: Yes.
answer: Let's just put this back here for the aromatherapy.

question: In another one...
answer: Hey, Pete, I'll be right with you.

question: You're all ready for football season, Mr. Graham.
answer: Yes, I think I nailed the personality profile of the women of Hale. No thanks.

question: He seems crabby. If you're looking for Elm Street, it's that way.
answer: Thank you.

question: If you came down here in the pursuit of happiness, you might as well go back. Because you can't make me feel bad.
answer: I'm not here to make you feel bad. I'm here for vindication. In my heart...

question: You have one?
answer: I feel I'm right about you. You got me fired, lady. You destroyed my reputation and you screwed up my hair. You chew men up, spit them out and loved it. And I'm down here to satisfy myself on that point.

question: Did something happen to make you care about reality?
answer: Yes. Conviction. Conviction that I'm onto the truth. You're going to do the same thing to "poor bastard number four" that you did to the last three. You're going to run again. And I'm not leaving until you do.

question: You're going to be very disappointed.
answer: We'll see.

question: I'd love to stay and chat, but I've got to get back to work. I still have my job. I have nothing to hide, Mr. Graham. Talk to whoever you want. You might actually stumble upon a fact or two.
answer: Hey, kid, I'll give you ten bucks for your hat.

question: Bob's the head of the P.E. department at the high school. And he coaches the football team. And he's climbed Everest.
answer: Everest. Is that right?

question: Twice...
answer: Really?

question: But he's got the Bobster's eyes.
answer: Sure. Here, Maggie. I think this makes the best you.

question: Let's see... Excuse me, isn't that cute? Ahh...
answer: You must be that Mr. Graham fellow.

question: Yes, I am. And who are you?
answer: Betty Trout. Five dollars.

question: Oh, Betty. I take it you're going to be making the wedding cake and they say you're throwing --
answer: -- The luau for Maggie.

question: At the wedding? You invite him? Bob, don't you realize he's writing another article about me?
answer: Sure I do. But the bet defense is a good offense, right? You're not going to let your opponent throw you off your game.

question: You don't understand this guy.
answer: Let him come to the wedding. You're not running, right? Say it. "I'm not..."

question: I'm not running.
answer: So if you're not running and Ike Graham is there to see it, then any article he writes has got to have a happy ending, right? All we're doing is turning lemon into lemonade.

question: I've got news for you. No amount of sugar and water is going to turn like Graham into something you want to take on a picnic.
answer: Where's that homemade sunshine?

question: Bless me, Father, for I have sinned. My last confession was... ahh... No -- like -- I'm having a problem with that whole turn-the-other-cheek concept. I want revenge. I want to destroy this guy's life, career, everything. On the sin scale, how big is that? I mean, can I "Hail Mary" my way out of it? The name's Maggie. It wasn't this side of ten years ago that you had your tongue down my throat. So don't call me "child", Brian. It annoys me. Brian, open up. Don't ignore me.
answer: You're not even Catholic, Maggie -- you really shouldn't come to confession.

question: I'm sorry. I'm just so stressed out about that slime-ball reporter being in town. I jus had to come warn you he might show up here and start asking you all kinds of ridiculous questions.
answer: Actually, he only asked me one ridiculous question. The rest weren't so bad.

question: What? You talked to him! Did you tell him we dated before you were a priest?
answer: Yes, yes, I'm sure I only did you good, Maggie.

question: What did he ask?
answer: No, no. Only respectful things. What did we have in common back then... What kind of music did you like... Did you ruin my life when you left me standing at the altar...

question: And what did you say?
answer: How could I be angry at you when clearly what has happened to me is as God intended?

question: Good one! Thanks.
answer: It happens to be how I feel.

question: God... Of course. I'm sorry -- I mean, I'm... Brian -- I've got to go. The man's a lunatic, but I know exactly where he's going next.
answer: God bless you, Maggie.

question: Oh, wait, my purse.
answer: He wanted to know how you used to like your eggs.

question: Weird. Like after all those years you would remem--
answer: -- Scrambled, with salt, pepper and dill. Same as me.

question: I'm really sorry that I hurt you, Brian.
answer: I'm happy here, where I'm supposed to be. But if you ever become a Catholic, may I ask you a favor, Maggie?

question: Of course.
answer: Could your confess to Father Patrick from now on?

question: Of course. Gill? Lydia? Gill?
answer: Hey -- I found it!

question: Found what?
answer: Mags! Hey, look -- The tape from the Radio City Music Hall concert -- Remember that night I as trying to get Jerry to let me sit in on "Ripple"?

question: Listen, Gill -- There's this reporter who's ben making my life a living hell ... If he comes by here, don't talk to him. And whatever yo do.... ... Don't show him that picture of me at the concert in San Francisco --
answer: We went to San Francisco twice. Remember one time we had a flat tire... Which picture?

question: Okay, he's on base. Can we talk about my life now? -- Ike's going to turn that tattoo stuff into a big deal -- that I was never serious about Gill, blah blah. He's totally out to get me.
answer: For what reason? Some personal satisfaction?

question: That's what he says, but if he thinks that I don't realize he's writing another article, then he's an idiot.
answer: It's probably because you got him fired.

question: Ya think?
answer: Not that he doesn't deserve to get fired... Look! Cory's going for second!... Sneaky!

question: There he is. Snoop Doggy-Dogg.
answer: Where?

question: Over there. Ten o'clock. He's talking to our little Dennis. Dennis will turn into one of those "sources say" things.
answer: He looks better with that stuff out of his hair. He's an attractive man.

question: I'd say you've been in the sun too long. You handle him, okay? I could use five minutes off from that creep.
answer: Okay, that's fine. I can do that.

question: Okay, that's fine. I can do that.
answer: Hello, Peggy Phleming, "not the ice-skater".

question: That's Maggie's seat...
answer: ... And this is Maggie's beer.

question: Have you listened to his morning show, "Wake up with ballplayer"?
answer: Not yet. I had a phlemless morning. I hear he's a pretty good ballplayer.

question: This game is pretty important to him. He made all-stars in high school, you know.
answer: That must have made you proud.

question: He was going with Maggie back then. He was never one of her... I mean, they were never going to get... They just dated for a while.
answer: It's nice that they're still friends.

question: You've been here for three minutes. What did you do to her?
answer: You can turn that finger around.

question: You misinterpret everything. We've all been friends our whole lives. But that's the types of relationship you wouldn't understand.
answer: Obviously, I'm not the only one who doesn't understand it. The USS Maggie leaves quite a wake... Excuse me.

question: See, I cheer good. What is he, a cheer critic? This guy never stops. Lee, hey, wake up. Give me the key to the reporter's room. I want to snoop around. Thanks. "How does she get all these guys to propose? She's not that beautiful." Bite me, paper boy.
answer: All right, I know you're in there... You steal my research... You're messing with the first amendment now. Open up. Open up. You got no place to go. I want to have a very serious discussion with you as to why you're such a pain in the ass.

question: You do that. And remind him he's bringing the wine to the luau. Thanks. Do you think I flirt with Cory?
answer: Good morning to you, too. You look good.

question: Thank you. Do you think I flirt with Cory?
answer: Yes.

question: I don't mean it.
answer: I know. I think sometimes you just sort of spaz-out with random excess flirtation energy and it just lands on anything male that moves.

question: On anything male that moves? As opposed to anything male that doesn't move?
answer: Like certain kinds of coral.

question: I'm going to kill myself.
answer: Why?

question: Because you think I'm all like... "Hey man, check me out".
answer: No, I don't think you're like, "I'm charming and mysterious in a way that even I don't understand and something about me is crying out for protection from a big man like you". Very hard to compete with. Especially to us married women who have lost our mystery.

question: But you haven't lost your mystery! You're very mysterious!
answer: No. I'm weird. Weird and mysterious are two different things.

question: But I'm weird.
answer: No. You're quirky. Quirky and weird are two different things.

question: Peggy, there's distinct possibility that I might be profoundly and irreversibly screwed up. Despite that, I love you and I can promise that I will no longer flirt with Cory, and I beg your forgiveness.
answer: I'm not worried about you and Cory or Cory and me or even that you're irreversibly screwed up. But, Maggie, you've been like this since we were kids. And I think now that you are aware of it and that it hurts people's feelings, maybe it's time to move on with your life and commit to someone of your own, like Bob, if he's the one.

question: I think you're right. Is there anything I can do to make it up to you?
answer: Something that brings warmth to my heart. Duckbill platypus.

question: It's only funny at Camp Birchwood at three in the morning at a tick hunt. It's not anymore.
answer: You're right. It's not funny now. Maybe we both grew up.

question: Thanks. Will you fix my hair? Freeze. Hold on to those covers -- I didn't come here to see Ike Junior.
answer: I take it the desk clerk is one of your many admirers.

question: How do I do it? I'm not that beautiful.
answer: Coffee. Now.

question: You're welcome. Your notes made interesting bedtime reading -- if you like trashy fiction. Your observations are distorted, ungrounded an incomplete. You must be very proud.
answer: I'm not a boastful man. What's your point?

question: My point is that one again, you're getting it all wrong. That won't improve your reputation any, and it's not very flattering to me either. So, I'm going to give you a chance to write the truth.
answer: Really.

question: I've decided to cooperate and let you interview me. For a thousand bucks.
answer: My magazine doesn't pay because for stories. It's not what you call ethical.

question: Oh, but making up the facts as you go along is ethical? Actually, I meant you. You probably got severance or expenses or both. I'll take your check. No credit cards.
answer: You've seen the post-its. I've already got more juicy material than I need. Why should I pay you dollar one?

question: Because I think you're writing on spec and with a first person interview, you might actually sell that thing.
answer: Too much.

question: Seven-fifty.
answer: Five hundred.

question: Six-fifty.
answer: Done.

question: Pardon the mess. I haven't cleaned since the fifth grade. It's a birthday present for my cousin. Put your finger in.
answer: Cindy the manicurist.

question: No, the other one.
answer: This is wonderful. You reconfigure all these industrial parts and you do something amazing with it.

question: I think so.
answer: I like it. This whole thing is pretty incredible. I think you could probably sell this lamp idea in New York.

question: Maybe someday.
answer: You afraid to try?

question: No, I'm not afraid. Just... Maybe someday.
answer: Well, I'm impressed. Absolutely incredible. I didn't expect pink and lacy, but this isn't exactly a woman's room.

question: What an incredible chauvinistic observation. That's Brian's. He took me ut canoeing on the lake and gave me the ring in a velvet box.
answer: Always a mood killer.

question: Still sweet.
answer: It's a little "Silence of the Lambs" for me. I can't believe you waited for the wedding to run.

question: He's an entomologist! I thought it was very unique.
answer: Wait. Don't tell me. The scoreboard lit up with "Mary me, Maggie."

question: It was one of the most wonderful moments of my life. Cal Ripken even applauded.
answer: Highly suspect.

question: What do you mean? It was incredibly romantic!
answer: Maybe it's just me, but -- if you got to dress it up, it doesn't ring true.

question: I like it.
answer: I'm a work in progress.

question: So? Is that what you said to her?
answer: No. I think I said something eloquent like, "So, uh -- maybe we should, ya know. What do you think?"

question: Now that's romantic. A proposal like that and you didn't find eternal bliss? What went wrong?
answer: I don't know.

question: You don't know.
answer: No.

question: Maybe you should ask her some time. Ever thought of that?
answer: Call me crazy, but I believe that check I gave you entitles me to ask the questions for a while.

question: Fair enough. Actually...
answer: Ow!

question: Even with everything that's happened I've still never been married and I still deserve a beautiful dress.
answer: Agreed.

question: Mr. Whittenmeyer. Hi, Polly! I didn't drag. He tripped on his shoelaces.
answer: You've come for your dress. Good! I'll get it from the back.

question: Actually, I would like to get this dress.
answer: Polly, take Leslie into change. But the one you have on hold is lovely.

question: Yes. But I've changed my mind.
answer: It's one thousand dollars.

question: I have one thousand dollars.
answer: The other one is only three hundred dollars.

question: Is this dress for sale?
answer: It just seems like an awful lot of money to spend on one of your dresses, Maggie... You only wear them for about ten minutes.

question: Mrs. Whittenmeyer. May I talk to you for a second?
answer: Yes. I've been here for thirty years.

question: Perfect. Because Miss Carpenter is here to buy one. But not just any one. She wants that one.
answer: It's a thousand dollars! Will he really do that? Shhhh! The man has ink!

question: Can you excuse us a minute? May I have a word with you, please?
answer: Bye, Netta... Bye, Grandam.

question: I found this and didn't know if it was something interesting.
answer: Oh, my God -- It's Miles Davis. This is "King of Blue"! This is the original recording. Hard to find in good condition. Where did you find this?

question: It was in the attic. It was jus sitting there gathering dust.
answer: It's valuable. Hang onto it.

question: No. You take it.
answer: Hmmm... Figuring out what kind of music I like and then finding me a rare album. You're not trying to soften me up, are you?

question: No -- I'm cleaning an attic. I wouldn't attempt the impossible. C'mon. Let's go.
answer: I haven't had any fun since you got your driver's license...

question: I'm not exactly having fun, either... Steady.
answer: Good boy, Port Hole.

question: His name is Skipper, Dad... Steady.
answer: I changed it. See you later, Mr. Travis. That guy has a problem... Maggie, you can run everyone's life but your own.

question: No. Forget about it. Don't even think about it.
answer: Watch your leg, Dad. I'm so tired of this.

question: Why don't you let him sleep it off in the trunk. I'll take you for a ride. Then we'll come back for him. Keep an eye on him. I was talking to the dog. All right?
answer: Okay... I'll just grab my jacket.

question: My dad managed a business and two mistresses. He wanted me to be a novelist. More?
answer: Your filter's clogged. This takes unleaded.

question: Can you fix it?
answer: First I have to find some tools. I need a half and a nine-six-tenth.

question: Of what?
answer: Wrenches. My dad's gonna love that one.

question: Kind of isolated.
answer: Yeah. It's kind of nice.

question: There's one thing we New Yorkers know how to do is hail a cab. If there's no cab, we walk.
answer: I can get some tools over there.... and save the battery... There's one thing we country girls know how to do is cut across a field. It's quicker.

question: Snakes? Are you serious? I don't like snakes. I've never even seen a snake.
answer: Do you think there's only one right person for everybody?

question: No. But I think attraction is too often mistaken for rightness. Attraction is very misleading. And if it's mutual, it's well, terribly distracting.
answer: Yes it is. And it doesn't mean anything.

question: Yeah, we need a half and nine- sixteenths. You're sure well known around here.
answer: Yes, well, my theory was that she may be running because she gets attention... Negative attention is attention. Like when women whack you on the street because of your column, that's negative attention.

question: This is about her negative attention, not mine. Did you get the reimbursement for the dress yet?
answer: No, I'm paying for the dress. Do you think she's still gonna run?

question: I don't know. Look -- I'll be in there later today. I'll come by and tell you all about it.
answer: You're coming here?

question: Yeah.
answer: Then come for dinner.

question: Okay, we'll order out.
answer: Order out like a Philistine, when you got the Galloping Gourmet here?...

question: Get this man a Kamikaze.
answer: Splendid dissection of Maggie Carpenter, very professional job.

question: You could have told me you were fiance number three.
answer: And end up in the papers? I've been humiliated enough already to last a lifetime, thank you. I'm sorry she got you canned.

question: Thanks.
answer: She's a cacophony of contradictions.

question: Well, I'm writing another article on the cacophony.
answer: Ah, can't stay away from her, can you? Like a moth to a flame.

question: Guess you'd know about that. You're an entomologist, right? How's business?
answer: Not bad. I was traveling around studying the reproductive and migratory patterns of locusts when Maggie met me.

question: Neuter a locust, feed the world.
answer: Same as you said. What did you call her? A "man-eater", "a devouring death goddess."

question: I don't think that's why she ran.
answer: Why do YOU think she ran?

question: I don't know. I'm working on it. I was on the wrong track.
answer: And you defending her?

question: No. I call it like I see it. I'm a journalist. I'm a truth teller.
answer: Unbelievable, she got to you.

question: Oh, please! I'm writing an article, I'm getting paid to do this, it's going to be a cover story, it's going to be published ... The facts will be read someday.
answer: Poached, just like me.

question: Yeah... Oh, Jay... Okay... Bye. Fisher, don't forget the fortune cookies.
answer: Is that what I did to you? Is that what happened? Did I just not see you?

question: No. No, you didn't.
answer: Well -- I'm sorry, I'm really sorry, Ellie.

question: Lighten up, wahine.
answer: Lighten up, what?

question: This party is for you and Bob. Get your mind off the reporter.
answer: I haven't seen him in twenty-four hours. It just gives me the creeps a little bit. I'd feel better if I knew where he was.

question: Would it?
answer: I'm going to go dance with Bob. Because he's the man. I like those grapes.

question: I don't know, give me a minute. Are you all right with this?
answer: Excuse me?

question: Are you all right with this? You think this is funny?
answer: Yes.

question: I'm the only goddamn person in there pulling for you.
answer: You humiliated me!

question: No, Maggie, I defended you. Humiliating you is what everyone else is doing. It's the theme of this party.
answer: I had it under control. Now they feel sorry for me.

question: Well, they should. Because they're about to watch you hang yourself again.
answer: It's fun! It's high.

question: Or the sexual habits of locusts?
answer: That was very interesting research George was doing!

question: What kind of Dead Head gets a temporary tattoo?
answer: I already explained about that.

question: And where you ever really going to run the leper colony in Molokai?
answer: Brian told you that?

question: Or maybe you just wanted to wear the headdress.
answer: Every one of those times I was being supportive. Something you won't understand.

question: Supportive? You weren't being supportive. You were being scared. Just like now. You are the most lost woman I have ever laid eyes on.
answer: Lost!

question: That's right. You're so lost you don't even know how you like your eggs.
answer: What!?

question: With the priest, you liked them scrambled. With the Dead Head, fried. With the bug guy, poached. Now it's egg whites only, thank you very much.
answer: That's called changing your mind.

question: No, that's called not having a mind of your own. What are you doing, Maggie? You really want to let that man drag you up Annapuma on your honeymoon? You don't want to climb Annapuma.
answer: Yes I do!

question: No you don't. You want a man who will lead you down the beach with his head over your eyes just so you can discover the feel of the sand under your feet. You want a guy who will take you into a cave with a thousand candles just to read you a poem. You want a man to wake you up at dawn because he's burning to talk to you and he can't wait another minute to find out what you'll say. Am I right?
answer: Stop. Stop it! I'm getting married on Sunday, and you're just trying to make me run! Why? Because you're a cynical, exploitative, mean-hearted creep who wouldn't know real love if it bit him in the armpit! And all you do is tear other people down and-and-and laugh at them, and criticize what they do, because you're too afraid to do anything yourself! I read your column. You never wrote one about you. I'm not the only one who's lost and you know it! Am I right? Well? Am I right?

question: Stop. Stop it! I'm getting married on Sunday, and you're just trying to make me run! Why? Because you're a cynical, exploitative, mean-hearted creep who wouldn't know real love if it bit him in the armpit! And all you do is tear other people down and-and-and laugh at them, and criticize what they do, because you're too afraid to do anything yourself! I read your column. You never wrote one about you. I'm not the only one who's lost and you know it! Am I right? Well? Am I right?
answer: Mag. Help me out here. Green Bay. Right guard.

question: Yes.
answer: Let me take you back inside, okay?

question: He's going to be the pastor?
answer: Yep. I want him to be front and center and to watch everything.

question: What happened at the luau?
answer: ... I don't even want to talk about the luau. What's this?

question: It's for the bell.
answer: Bob's in a hurry.

question: Don't be nervous, Maggie. Let us visualize. Remember what Bob said? "Be the ball."
answer: "Sink the putt."

question: "Make the shot."
answer: "Nothing but net."

question: Okay. So... what, uh... What just happened? Just now? Jus then? In there?
answer: I don't know. I, uh -- I frankly don't even want to talk about it.

question: Me, either.
answer: I love you. I love you.

question: I love you, too.
answer: Wait. We have to talk. We have to do some talking now. Pull up a railing.

question: To who? Are you asking me?
answer: Me?

question: Yes, you!
answer: Well, you do have the dress.

question: And the church.
answer: And the wedding date. There's the two of us. So, you think... maybe... You have to go down the aisle with somebody you love and who love you back.

question: I'm okay with that.
answer: So am I.

question: So, we'll...
answer: I'm getting married.

question: Grandma!
answer: See, this is a mature relationship. She's really found it.

question: He's not coming. Watch. He's not coming.
answer: No, no. I saw eight geese flying in a "V".

question: You and your lucky geese. You always see geese.
answer: Not eight...

question: No, I'm not. Friends. Thank you. Thank you.
answer: Of course we are. Of course.

question: Then you'll be my best man.
answer: Well, I'm good, I don't know if I'm best.

question: You look awful.
answer: Thank you.

question: Ike. Need help?
answer: Really?

question: I didn't want to find out I wasn't for her in the fourth quarter.
answer: Got any last minute advice?

question: Maintain eye contact.
answer: Eye contact. Eye contact.

question: Hi, I'm Elaine from New York.
answer: Hello. I'm Bob, Maggie's fourth attempt.

question: I'm sorry.
answer: That's okay. There's a lid for every pot. Besides, I'm comfortable with Ike. I mean, Jack Dempsey lost his heavyweight title to a New Yorker.

question: You okay? I'm closing.
answer: I'm just finishing up, too.

question: Want to go to Butch's for a drink or something?
answer: No, I'm just going to head home.

question: Okay.
answer: What are you talking about?

question: Wedding. Wedding. You just have to get the rest of your ducks in a row.
answer: Thank you. You still think that he was....

question: Quick. Very quick.
answer: Hi, Dennis. You're sweet, Dennis. But you've got to go. I'm closing up. Here's a candy bar and one for your brother.

question: Honey, your grandmother and I were thinking about opening a wedding gift museum.
answer: STOP!

question: What?
answer: Just stop it. Don't say another word like that.

question: Maggie, it's just a joke...
answer: No. It's my life.

question: A harmless joke.
answer: No, it's humiliating and you've been doing it since I was a kid. I don't like it. Stop. You may not like having a daughter with problems. But guess what? I don't like having a father who's drunk all the time. I'll eat in my room.
